title: Drug driver blames girlfriend for crash after leaving her to die alone
text:
Adrian Paskin, 35, left girlfriend Sarah Handley, 28, in the back seat (Picture: PA)

A man who left his girlfriend to die at the scene of a car crash shouted at her family that the collision was her fault.

Adrian Paskin, 35, was four times over the limit and had no licence or insurance when he got behind the wheel of his Ford Fiesta on August 17 earlier this year.

He was then requested to pull over by police, but instead attempted to speed away, even driving on the pavement to evade officers.

Paskin then ploughed into a Volkswagen Golf carrying a family-of-three at 100mph, before abandoning Sarah Handley, 28, in the back seat with a serious head injury.

The mum-of-one, from West Bromwich, was pronounced dead shortly after the collision in Crocketts Road, Birmingham.

He was four times over the drug-driving limit (Picture: PA)

Birmingham Crown Court was shown CCTV footage of the crash before hearing a victim impact statement from Ms Handley’s father Malcolm.

Mr Handley said of his daughter, who leaves behind a son, nine: ‘She was a loving daughter, mum and granddaughter. She was no angel at times but we all loved her dearly.

‘He did not stop to think of anyone else except himself while Sarah lay dying in the back of that car.’

Paskin then interrupted the statement by shouting from the dock: ‘Your daughter didn’t want me to stop the car. That’s why I didn’t stop.’

The defendant was first made the subject of a police marker when he failed to stop for a patrol car in the early hours.

Prosecutor Aliya Rashid told the court he had been wearing a mask, and said his speeds had gone up to 90mph in 30 to 40mph roads during the first pursuit.

Officers abandoned the car chase in Ladywood, Birmingham, but Paskin was later spotted by police at 9.30pm on the M6, near Walsall.

Ms Handley suffered a serious head injury in the crash (Picture: PA)

He then sped through red lights and drove on the pavement before crashing one minute after officers called off the pursuit.

Witnesses said they believed he was driving at speeds of 100mph when he collided with Volkswagen Golf head-on.

Paskin, who used heroin and cocaine and did not have any lights on, was found to be four-times over the drug-driving limit.

The court heard he had previous convictions for 67 offences, including 10 of driving while disqualified, and was previously jailed for dangerous driving in 2007 and 2015.

Paskin pleaded guilty to dangerous driving, causing death by dangerous driving, having no insurance, and driving otherwise than in accordance with a licence at a previous hearing.

He was sentenced to nine years and four months behind bars and given a driving ban of 12 years and eight months.

Judge Melbourne Inman QC told the defendant that his behaviour during sentencing was ‘utterly deplorable’.

He said: ‘I don’t punish you for that but it’s clearly beyond doubt that you appear to have no remorse. Your only concern appears to be yourself and nobody else, including sadly Sarah and her family.’

description: Adrian Paskin, 35, crashed his Ford Fiesta into a Volkswagen Golf before abandoning girlfriend Sarah Handley with a serious head injury.
